etymologies: early 19th century; earliest use found in Edinburgh Medical and Surgical Journal. From humour + -ism, after humorist

definitions: The theory that health, disease, and temperament are determined by the four humours of the body, or by bodily fluids generally; = humoralism.

notes.text: In later use chiefly in critical works relating to foreign (especially Italian) literature.

definitions: A humorous or witty saying or remark.
